subject: Starting out as well...
msgSnippet: I ve been following the activities of this group, which has been quite prolific, for the past couple of years, but I ve yet to take the time to actually learn
messageBody:
I've been following the activities of this group, which has been quite
prolific, for the past couple of years, but I've yet to take the time
to actually learn the Read Alphabet. I am just about to take this on,
and I'm in the process of trying out fonts for my Mac -- so please
excuse in advance my ignorance about this alphabet...

Anyway, much like Rachel in a related posting, over the years I've
used shorthand-like scripts that I've invented myself for my own use.
One thing that I discovered in the process is that English spelling
(or the attitude towards it) permits much variation, be it regional or
temporal, in pronunciation.

I'm wondering if this has been discussed in this forum? How does
Quikscript allow for the ever-changing pronunciation of English as it
evolves over time (and across borders)? Is the spelling of words
changed merely based upon who is saying them?

Also, about shapes of the glyphs themselves, they don't appear to flow
nicely from one to the next. I'm wondering why some "natural"
alphabet, such as Arabic, has not been retrofitted to English if a
quick and flowing way to write is the intended goal?

regards,
Michael
